choices.D: The output is Can't tell if x and y are equal or not.

discussion.content: D is right

Yes, D is the right answer. Explanation : When a variable is not initiated or it is defined NULL in that case we cannot make any comparisons with other variables like either it is equal or not equal. In any case comparisons will be FALSE.

comments.content: C is not correct, you won't get an error on compilation, you will get the error on runtime.
C is correct, you can not use DCL statements in side the triggers.

CREATE TABLE audit_cust (
 user_name VARCHAR2(50),
 change_time DATE,
 cust_id NUMBER,
 old_credit_limit NUMBER,
 new_credit_limit NUMBER
);
/

Table AUDIT_CUST created.

CREATE OR REPLACE TRIGGER tr_audit_cust AFTER
 UPDATE OF salary ON emp1
 FOR EACH ROW
BEGIN
 INSERT INTO audit_cust (
 user_name,
 change_time,
 cust_id,
 old_credit_limit,
 new_credit_limit
 ) VALUES (
 user,
 sysdate,
 :old.employee_id,
 :old.salary,
 :new.salary
 );

 COMMIT;
END;
/

Trigger TR_AUDIT_CUST compiled

UPDATE emp1
SET
 salary = NULL
WHERE
 department_id = '20';
/

ORA-04092: cannot COMMIT in a trigger
ORA-06512: at "HR.TR_AUDIT_CUST", line 16
ORA-04088: error during execution of trigger 'HR.TR_AUDIT_CUST'

D is correct.

discussion.content:
C is correct , you cant use commit or rollback in the trigger.
The transaction made in trigger is commited by the normal flow of the program that fired the trigger
It compiles successfully, but gives an error when the credit limit is updated in the CUSTOMER table because the PRAGMA AUTONOMOUS_TRANSACTION statement should be introduced in the trigger.

choices.B: It compiles and fires successfully when the credit limit is updated in the customer table.
choices.C: It gives an error on compilation because of the commit command in the trigger code.
choices.A: It gives an error on compilation because it should be a statement-level trigger.
choices.D: It compiles successfully, but gives an error when the credit limit is updated in the CUSTOMER table because the PRAGMA AUTONOMOUS_TRANSACTION

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about anonymous blocks and subprograms? (Choose three.)

choices.D: It gives an error because both the MAX and DECODE functions can be used only in a SQL statement.
choices.C: It gives an error because the SUBSTR and INSTR functions can be used only in a SQL statement.
choices.B: It gives an error because the DECODE function can be used only in a SQL statement.

comments.content:
Answer B is the right answer. Not all the functions are allowed in a pl/sql block. In this case for decode you will get the error ORA-06550: line 4, column 10:
PLS-00204: function or pseudo-column 'DECODE' may be used inside a SQL statement only
you can use every sql function in pl/sql block so I think A is good.

discussion.content: The right answer would be B. It gives an error because the DECODE function can be used only in a SQL statement.

you can use DECODE and GROUP FUNCTION in SQL statements inside PL/SQL not in procedurals statements.
After testing:

ORA-06550: Ligne 13, colonne 5 :
PL/SQL: Statement ignored
06550. 00000 - "line %s, column %s:\n%s"
*Cause: Usually a PL/SQL compilation error.
*Action:"
so B is the correct answer
B is correct. You can use 'DECODE' in PL/SQL block only if it's part of SELECT statement
